E945DA151F81485DB3EEDCCDA5557908.description: Provide feedback on own and/or peer business plans.

44CAE33F897840A6BD62B8D10700A043.description: Outline and present a plan for a small business in the wildlife industry (e.g., guide, game farm, aquafarm, meat processing and taxidermy) in one's community.

D621B6137AC240B98CE30388299A1C68.description: Explain the importance of sustainable business practices such as providing good quality customer service, following environmental guidelines and employing qualified and certified personnel.

739758A3B1F347828A67FD05A0DE3266.description: Research the requirements (e.g., registering for collecting and remitting taxes, licensing, zoning, obtaining permits and registering the business name) for establishing a small business in one's community.

75F1310012B045AA8C16B9B17025CE2D.description: Inquire about the common characteristics and qualifications of a successful small business owner in the wildlife industry.

480F9F4412794F59A710E4BDDB37FDB8.description: Classify examples of wildlife and habitat management businesses within one's community as home-based, sole proprietorship, partnership and/or franchise businesses.

48D86A5F229F423290C3EBD99AB755DE.description: Discuss the importance of legislation and/or regulations that govern the wildlife industry in Saskatchewan.

3C564CED7CCB4047B0A06E36C8866CA4.description: Explore the role of cooperatives as a business model and their impact on the provincial economy.

D28ED9544F8B4409842CF7FA167105DD.description: Investigate the advantages and disadvantages of owning a sole proprietorship, partnership and/or franchise business.

04755511605F4F1FAEB5705285BB2C32.description: Discuss the advantages and disadvantages of operating a small business, including a home-based business.

D100B72BD4E8490F9794C8D36FFA4B8E.description: Research the contributions that small businesses make to the local and Saskatchewan economy.

B5127F9E423D4E47AD67E42540677360.description: Investigate small business opportunities, including home-based businesses, in the wildlife and habitat industry in Saskatchewan.

81AB1A10A3F54DC49C122C7EF259DCCE.description: Develop and/or revise personal and career goals based on the work placement experience.

6B8E98946C2E4EAA8861DBEE01611342.description: Prepare a letter, note, card or other communication for the work placement employer, expressing appreciation.

0F31BC23D7614FF4B0C244F7C7201463.description: Update personal career documentation (e.g., resume, portfolio) following the work placement.

CDCE832FBE27467E8246F322338320C9.description: Reflect on the attainment of personal and learning goals.

3024F52C124F4846916EC87939DB908B.description: Showcase one's skills and abilities demonstrated during the work placement using artifacts, evidence of skill development and personal reflections on aspects of the work experience such as: hours worked; responsibilities and tasks performed; the importance of attitude towards work and taking responsibility for what needs to be done; details about the entry level wage, salary scales and earning potential; worker rights and responsibilities and the role of the union, if applicable; ownership structure (e.g., corporation, franchise, sole proprietorship, partnership); and, opportunities for advancement at the workplace and elsewhere in the industry.

FBAB0A2BD3624F1C836D7E14F8CA8BA8.description: Relate one's work placement experience to personal and career goals.

1F87DFA395D04411A8E8C56D7A87C1E6.description: Document knowledge and awareness of employment standards, safety, workplace ethics, rights and responsibilities, occupational health and safety, and networking observed during the work placement.

2D093FA9099B48DCA57890EE9A7BBF67.description: Document one's experience using electronic and other tools (e.g., vlogs, blogs, log sheets, reflective journals) to summarize and reflect upon items such as: hours of work including breaks; responsibilities and tasks performed; interactions with the employer, staff, customers and others; company or organization's 'raison d'être;' and, skills developed and demonstrated during the work placement that enhance one's employability.

A7917815FE4E45EEBC69413DC435F2CC.description: Apply relevant skills and abilities during the work placement experience.

DF2035E6424E409CB383123ADB0F1A88.description: Participate in a work placement experience.

196D2BA9B7E74039812BDF903E3FAC82.description: Reflect upon one's performance during the interview.

3A6B0E7DEE5B41FE82CFAE5B3256482B.description: Participate in an interview with the employer prior to beginning the work placement.

EE69196381194239802B7E516CBDBDDF.description: Develop a list of questions that could potentially be asked by the employer/work placement in an interview situation as well as answers to the questions.

AD82694B796A4AB08255B301668BF018.description: Brainstorm a list of questions to ask the employer before beginning the work placement. These may include: What is my schedule of work hours?, Who is my supervisor?, What should I wear?, When will I be provided with safety training?, What potential hazards might I encounter in the work placement?, Where do I find fire extinguishers, first aid kits and emergency assistance?, What type of safety gear am I expected to wear? Is it, provided?, What should I do if I get injured or have an accident in the workplace?, How can I contact my health and safety committee or representative?, Are there any health and safety procedures I should follow?, Who is the first aid person?, Where are safety notices posted?, What should I do in case of a fire or emergency?

F4EDE017C2C9474BBD3F77B6656B1DCC.description: Compile an employer information package that includes documents needed for the work placement (e.g., personal career documentation such as a resume or portfolio, permission forms, logs, self- and employer evaluation forms).

60FC2FDCA1314922A700B5A40D335323.description: Develop a procedural guide for the work placement that includes items such as: transportation to and from the work placement; hours of work; guidelines for absence and tardiness; dress code; job description; and, conflict resolution

A0839E6D9E3A42D58F1E6C47F1537937.description: In collaboration with all partners, develop personal and learning goals for the work placement.

E2B7C8F54D64451298A5DB2BF475C8F5.description: Research the business/organization to become familiar with its operations.

09E6DCC2816543F687513F5B0EA28C0A.description: Explain the roles and responsibilities of each partner (e.g., student, parent, teacher or other school staff, employer) involved in the work placement.

B0A69A204C72486999ABA0E0BE5362C2.description: Describe and reflect on the three basic rights that all workers have under Part III - Occupational Health and Safety in The Saskatchewan Employment Act, 2019: the right to know - the hazards at work and how to control them; the right to participate - in finding and controlling workplace hazards; and, the right to refuse - work that you believe is unusually dangerous.

6787ADF3676C4ED094CAFBBF3C147DF1.description: Construct a tool (e.g., rubric, checklist, self-evaluation form or peerevaluation form) to assess the process and products involved in a studentdeveloped management plan.

4D1805C9741E402CA8786FD3A1E96D12.description: Share the wildlife and habitat management plan through a display, presentation, performance, demonstration, fine art representation, video or research paper.

F2D2846CA745419FA9C91AE0E72D67F5.description: Consider the views of different stakeholders (e.g., recreational users, environmentalists, Indigenous people and commercial industries) in the management plan.

D1FE1DE547B54A73A2F8B7C76D1350CF.description: Identify potential consequences and alternative means of achieving management goals.

1DA437337EEC4F95B1CFCEC1B06AB173.description: Prepare a map (e.g., boundaries, resources in the area, physical features, history of past development, road access and proposed development) to accompany and support the management plan.

C98A8F0CAA4449908D4831DF1534839E.description: Describe techniques for monitoring the management plan to ensure goals are achieved.

985A8E92DF7E4011AD63C07B5B992E3F.description: Develop a data-based action plan, including a desired future state, goals and strategies, to address a specific wildlife and habitat management issue.

16C465773A1848259DFA7997304EA616.description: Assess the extent to which a wildlife and habitat management issue (e.g., habitat loss, climate change and disease) is evident within a local context.

8078A40E525F4866B1931F9C63F4C73D.description: Analyze data to make predictions regarding the health of a wildlife population and/or ecosystem.

B32B7B4EC2BF4D40852E47ACAB8D8007.description: Gather information from a variety of sources (e.g., student-developed surveys, consultations, research studies, case studies or other statistical methods) on an issue pertaining to wildlife species and habitats.

80AA39AAA812430089870A67D394164A.description: Discuss ideas for topics, questions or issues pertaining to wildlife species and habitats.

5288498C4E2C47E5AF53E50532DFC2DB.description: Develop a wildlife and habitat management plan.

12297617186143A6AFED130E7C57BDFC.description: Plan a menu for the excursion that addresses considerations such as:  group size; nutrition and diet requirements; length of excursion and cost; minimal packaging; and, food spoilage.

A4E3E92492744706994638C149436F3D.description: Critique possible sites for campsite selection with consideration of: site exposure and drainage; weather considerations (e.g., protection from wind); access to water and firewood; impact on flora and fauna; and, proximity to potential dangers.

A67D9576F05C468BA034BA51BECA8619.description: Review forms of communication when traveling to remote areas, such as: pre-arranged communication plans; filing a route plan with someone not on the excursion; and, ensuring means of communication beyond cell phone coverage (e.g., satellite phone and messaging device).

521E49F95C734B848ED6D3AF06CBDB28.description: Examine alternatives to equipment that may better supply needs or lessen impact on the environment.

322E84C886224BF1B11AB39FC458869B.description: Inspect and prepare equipment (e.g., life jackets, paddles, bike tires and camp stoves) for the excursion.

29D25067BDF24800B4A85A8C59C1845F.description: Discuss the importance of, and methods for ensuring, personal hygiene when spending multiple days outdoors.

58CA1051DC944B41938AA68CDC9B8620.description: Explain how clothing and packing choices are influenced by factors such as: season and weather; minimal space for packing; and, safe-carry weight (i.e., limiting packs to appropriate weight for body size and ability).

2701928977934F3DA5D16F3D271FA124.description: Explore possible activities appropriate for the season and group, such as hiking, canoeing, cycling, skiing or snowshoeing into camp.

9638045740DD45E7BA417CF242989F81.description: Reflect upon the traditional stories of the land where the multi-night outdoor excursion will take place.

9FD2F249F48740DD9AD34E0967E358CA.description: Discuss the importance of land acknowledgements (e.g., naming the traditional peoples of the area, identifying the treaty and partnerships with local Indigenous people) when participating in multi-night outdoor excursions.

996B51F0FD7045468E31346E19AC5E1A.description: Plan and facilitate a multi-night outdoor excursion.

CEF8D165A5F34DADB9A353E596B2B857.description: Explain how the Committee on the Status of Endangered Wildlife in Canada (COSEWIC) influences legislation.

8442F7C698AB4097B3F5EF7198031921.description: Examine different levels of wildlife protection legislation (i.e., provincial and federal) and their connection to non-profit organizations.

ADE9126CF06044948F7A6DCC36060031.description: Investigate the role of public and private organizations, including wildlife sanctuaries and rescue facilities, in mitigating threats to wildlife.

0C130B2ACB2B488C9EAC51B901D23056.description: Explain the significance of biodiversity in preventing disease.

3175180D563742C0BE58E79B8D88E925.description: Explore how wildlife can become a vector for transmission of diseases to humans (e.g., rabies, lyme disease, West Nile virus and coronavirus disease).

156287A100B346E0946A1304BCC371D1.description: Explain the relationship between stressed wildlife habitats and zoonosis (i.e., unhealthy habitat leads to prevalence and mutation of wildlife disease).

D10F9E4A4C0D4556A7320398CDBB0640.description: Investigate diseases that are a threat to Saskatchewan wildlife, such as: anthrax; avian influenza and newcastle disease in birds; brainworm or moose sickness in cervids; chronic wasting disease; ticks and tick-borne diseases; and, viral hemorrhagic septicemia in fish.

CB3A3FC0145E474783CD0D43013A6AEB.description: Research the impact of invasive animal species (e.g., wild boars) and aquatic species (e.g., zebra mussels) on local wildlife.

5330F855CE4A41E08201BF064E8E4D28.description: Investigate the impact that industrial activity (e.g., mining, hydroelectric, forestry and agriculture) has on ecosystems and wildlife populations.

6D1338AEE0DC4198B09C373E9AB8CBC5.description: Examine strategies used to bring at-risk wildlife populations back to healthy levels.

9721FF0BF1F142E7B2242E38724AB049.description: Discuss factors that affect wildlife populations within selected ecoregions of Saskatchewan and Canada, such as habitat loss, climate change, commercial harvest and disease.

BE1BABD360504F31BC3369DAA92C2BDF.description: Investigate provincial and federal measures used to determine if a species or population is endangered.

091B381EC31A43448F292D30EC224244.description: Identify Saskatchewan and Canadian wildlife species that are extinct, extirpated, endangered, threatened or a species of concern.

1F08005D2FF14F18B2B60F34014C6E64.description: Relate the concepts of “limiting factors” and “carrying capacity” to wildlife populations.

3C591AE87B6E435A9EB9F276763E5C1E.description: Describe the effects a species' population cycle has on another species (e.g., arctic hare and arctic fox).

55E2FFDA494E446F95D0DA28D253C445.description: Investigate the impact that overpopulated wildlife species in Saskatchewan have on other species and the environment.

7AA76E274C124D2496109D3A32897024.description: Analyze what the results of a population study indicate about the health of the species and the environment.

3714CFBB485245E092781A2291F3150A.description: Explain the purpose of completing a bird survey.

A8D89D2F3CC94E1BAB69AE8B64BC8C97.description: Explore methods for studying migratory birds, including bird banding.

03341ED769EE4D86B59B1C20252DF804.description: Use a variety of resources (e.g., Knowledge Keeper, books and technological applications) to identify birds in a given ecosystem.

9FBC53148802479B986A028E85F7AF73.description: Conduct a population study using an appropriate method, such as: scat analysis (e.g., deer and rabbit density); pond dipping; and, fish trapping or seine netting.

4CF14FB820C1437DBA05F45E2C7529A3.description: Compare various scientific methods (e.g., quadrat study, interpolation, stem count and estimating) used to count populations.

A61B8486AB48468CA730B6C70D5E18C8.description: Discuss the reasons for studying wildlife populations, including: understanding the impact of environmental change; game management; and, monitoring threatened species.

682F82B9EA844E01A703A4DCD6FCF5AD.description: Discuss the cultural and traditional stories and knowledge about the relationship between animals and Indigenous people with an Elder or Knowledge Keeper.

737CD3E736734C158376DA5B384C67CC.description: Examine the methods and reasons for monitoring wildlife populations.

00C175A1F93942B7B9632ED0065C1BE3.description: Investigate strategies for managing Saskatchewan’s fish populations, including: fishing regulations; fish stocking or augmentation; monitoring population; aquatic habitat development and improvement; law enforcement; and, public information programs.

98390E46EF3144E7B4086E5EDE598ACF.description: Explain the role of the Provincial Fisheries Management Plan in managing fish populations in Saskatchewan.

EA8E6CD590D340C4AC729BEDA6C17EAA.description: Identify non-native species (e.g., trout) that have been introduced for sport fishing in Saskatchewan.

38CB5FCEF8D84969B55AB6153E3D2953.description: Explain strategies (e.g., clean, drain and dry boats between bodies of water) to mitigate the spread of invasive aquatic species.

2E6E55A64F5B45D2A64FB9E6349F5749.description: Research the effects (e.g., reducing biodiversity and habitat quality) of aquatic invasive species (e.g., zebra and quagga mussels) in Saskatchewan.

77E462E94C1F42D7B052265A252BB824.description: Conduct a pond-dipping study to analyze what the invertebrate population indicates about the fish species.

D5AF0CAA8E494A3A93B6F5CD8ABAD1B0.description: Explore the water characteristics (e.g., still or moving, temperature, dissolved oxygen, depth, alkalinity and acidity) that influence the distribution and abundance of fish.

02813B2380B443AD927EBAC1E8E40D81.description: Examine the habitats that make the Saskatchewan ecozones, and corresponding treaty territories, conducive to fish species (e.g., rocky, deep lakes of the Boreal Shield are good for walleye).

60F3B784B15B47EA86CF471DCCE83803.description: Examine the relationship between fish populations and the aquatic environment.

CA0A886124E543819722043B610A7AE9.description: Conduct and analyze the results of a plant study (e.g., quadrat sampling, stem counts and population studies).

B73B09CD5308412682D43E6A9D454B7C.description: Explain the threats that invasive species (e.g., leafy spurge, purple loosestrife, downy brome, wild parsnip and yellow star thistle) pose to wildlife and habitats in Saskatchewan.

4AC8C73081AD434DAD14A6C1F9686C4B.description: Describe identifying characteristics of local plants that are potentially harmful (e.g., poison ivy, stinging nettle and wild parsnip) or poisonous (e.g., death camas and water hemlock).

C141D0ED23D049519AE451D4D384DC13.description: Investigate the risks of inappropriate consumption of medicinal plants.

3447BF21D2F944F8960068B4B5D813EF.description: Explore the medicinal qualities of local plants, such as: rat root and willow bark for pain relief; Labrador tea for sore throat and chest ailments; and, Balsam fir paste for cuts and burns.

4EA89A4A67C0465C9636AB04C9EF732E.description: Describe the economic value of local plants (e.g., lumber industry and food source).

904F6C31376B4FBA89F55171D4CDE589.description: Explain the significance of harvesting plants in the context of Indigenous food sovereignty.

A0E6D6A6C9CE4C21A26D0A2EE4E29B4F.description: Practise ethical harvesting through acts of mindfulness (e.g., take only what is needed) and gratitude (e.g., offering tobacco).

01EFB17477B2461DACAC338585E9A992.description: Explore traditional, medicinal and contemporary uses of local plants.

2DDDFE7FC7794CDF9EDF03592BCB7528.description: Research historical Indigenous-led applications of fire and cultural burning as part of forest and grassland succession and regeneration.

DBE524B0AE0242FFA07BBFEDB2A382AA.description: Exercise caution and proper procedures when using tools to process firewood, such as pocketknives for kindling and saws for cutting.

31D4173AF6A9480284E53A746B4094DF.description: Discuss possible solutions (e.g., curl stick) to the challenges (e.g., weather elements and lack of dry fuel) of igniting and maintaining a safe fire.

A5736D85467F40EF8905E4B35694E068.description: Experiment with different styles of fire-building, such as tipi, log cabin, star, platform, pyramid, lean-to, Swedish and upside down.

408AFBA9152D4DEC9C501E2E2353DAD6.description: Explore benefits of (e.g., minimal environmental impact), and options for (e.g., fire box or enviro-stove, roaster, rocket stove, gas stove and tin cans), contained fires.

B5D75F0CCAD9447880E196A084BCCB0A.description: Practise safely lighting fires with a variety of fuel sources such as tinder (e.g., natural, synthetic and chemical), home-made fire-starters (e.g., hand sanitizer, cotton balls or dryer lint and Vaseline) and kindling.

8888DC265B5E4CB8BA47C652F9C3A99B.description: Investigate a variety of ignition sources, such as: matches (e.g., paper, wood, water-proof and wind-proof); lighters (e.g., rotary, butane torch, electronic and reusable match stick); ferro rod; percussion (e.g., flint and steel); lens-based (e.g., magnifying glass, eye glasses and bottles); reflection-based (e.g., mirrors and polished pop can bottom); electric (e.g., batteries and steel wool, and electronic lighters); and, friction-based (e.g., fire piston, hand drill, bow drill and fire plough).

6E184A29BFA24B029EF2ED5C3F50853D.description: Describe the importance of safe fire-building practices in preventing personal injury and environmental damage.

AB021B44997E4D8CA2FECBF85D3B5010.description: Apply respectful and safe fire-building skills in a variety of conditions.

A83198A51E3D4F80B433A5C5E4B715B8.description: Explore opportunities and skills required for knife safety certification (e.g., Scouts Canada).

18FD910959484E6DADEDFA3EE1DA0EFB.description: Experiment with advanced knifecraft projects such as: crafting a diamond willow walking stick or a try stick; processing firewood and kindling; carving a netting needle or willow whistle; and, creating deadfall traps.

338629E3A3CF40EB9D3E0FC3B0A5F380.description: Describe the characteristics and purpose of different knives when processing game, such as: gutting (e.g., removing organs); boning (e.g., separating meat from bone); skinner (e.g., cutting the skin without tearing); and, filleting (e.g., cutting the meat from the fish).

1264C14E070148B0B2EDB7A8FBC97128.description: Apply safe knife care techniques (e.g., drying and oiling) to maintain knives.

9BF609327F8245CD8FE49BA0AE8E5314.description: Practise different knife sharpening techniques (e.g., strop, honing oil and sharpening board).

283279DA37524313AF8C243B075DA9A2.description: Explain the safety benefits of maintaining a sharp knife.

A048FB8C83514E0F8DEB28E25C64AC38.description: Apply safe, advanced knife skills for a variety of purposes.
